column16: Description of Program
column18: Ave. # of hours of all digital programming per week
column19: Ave. # of hours per week of digital Core Programming per week
column20: Y or N to Q 11 in Digital Core Programming: At least 50% of the Core Programming had not already aired within the previous seven days

column16: Jack Hanna's Animal Adventures is a live-action program designed to meet the educational and informational needs of children between the ages of 13 and 16. Each episode follows Jack Hanna as he spends time with animals from all continents. Jack interviews people knowledgeable about each animal and their habitat. Children will learn about ecology, respnosibility for the environment and sharing the planet with the animals.

Jack Hanna's Animal Adventures is a live-action program designed to meet the educational and informational needs of children between the ages of 13 and 16. Each episode follows Jack Hanna as he spends time with animals from all continents. Jack interviews people knowledgeable about each animal and their habitat. Children will learn about ecology, respnosibility for the environment and sharing the planet with the animals.

Jack Hanna's Animal Adventures is a live-action program designed to meet the educational and informational needs of children between the ages of 13 and 16. Each episode follows Jack Hanna as he spends time with animals from all continents. Jack interviews people knowledgeable about each animal and their habitat. Children will learn about ecology, respnosibility for the environment and sharing the planet with the animals.

Jack Hanna's Animal Adventures is a live-action program designed to meet the educational and informational needs of children between the ages of 13 and 16. Each episode follows Jack Hanna as he spends time with animals from all continents. Jack interviews people knowledgeable about each animal and their habitat. Children will learn about ecology, respnosibility for the environment and sharing the planet with the animals.

In this series, a young adult host - together with Blue, a puppy whose personality and actions mirror those of a preschooler - brings viewers a variety of games, themes and concepts that are based on an age-appropriate educational curriculum. The program follows a narrative format, in which the host elicits contributions from the viewer to answer questions and move the action forward. The program's objectives include encouraging preschoolers to actively explore the world around them, fostering their problem-solving skills and independent reasoning, and creating a foundation of confidence and optimism for future learning. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

In this series seven-year-old Dora and her monkey travel companion Boots invite the audience to join them each week on a journey in which they will have to overcome various obstacles to reach an end goal. The series uses a CD-ROM/on-line adventure game format to encourage a variety of problem-solving strategies. The objectives of this program are to assist children in developing their problem-solving skills, reinforce their emerging cognitive skills, and make computers more familiar to them by introducing and using the conventions and vocabulary of computer games. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

Based on the famous books written by Else Homelund Minarik and illustrated by Maurice Sendak, this series follows the spirited adventures of its curious, imaginative and inventive character Little Bear and his childhood friends. From the safety of his loving home and family, Little Bear explores his world and learns new things about himself and others, seeking a small measure of independence within a protected environment. The objectives of the program are to encourage preschoolers to be curious, creative and imaginative and to illustrate for them the value of good relationships with parents and friends and of such traits as loyalty, generosity and empathy. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

This is an animated series based on children's books written by Bill Cosby that examines life through the eyes of a five-year-old boy eager to understand his world. Each episode contains two stories in which Little Bill is faced with a challenge or problem - whether emotional, social or physical - he must solve. The objectives of this series are to encourage children to value themselves and the love and support of their family, friends and community, and to help them develop their social skills and ethical values by dealing with the conflicts in their lives with fairness and creativity. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

Based on a series by Paulette Bourgeois and Brenda Clark, this program features the adventures of the turtle Franklin and his friends Bear, Snail, Rabbit and Goose. The objectives of the program are to present to young viewers age-appropriate moral dilemmas addressing issues such as the meaning of right and wrong, the purposes of rules and the consequences of following or not following them, and the values inherent in telling the truth, and to teach viewers important social values such as cooperation and compromise, fairness, responsibility, self-respect and respect for others. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

This series, based on the children's books by author/illustrator Mick Inkpen, follows a little dog Kipper and his friends. Fueled by Kipper's active imagination, a simple scenario at the start of each episode leads into a story of fantasy and humor, intended to help viewers explore their feelings and thoughts, as well as use their imagination. The objectives of the program are to assist preschoolers in their personal and social development, encourage them to test their own skills and abilities, and introduce them to concepts of cooperation with and care for others. This program is specifically designed to further the educational and informational needs of children, has educating and informing children as a significant purpose, and otherwise meets the definition of Core Programming as specified in the Commission's rules.

"Popular Mechanics for Kids" features two young reporters who visit some of the world's most exciting places to get a "hands-on" demonstration of what it takes to build and operate everything they see. The program received a 1998 Parents' Choice recommendation, a 1998 Silver Apple Award from the National Educational Media Network, and a "highly educational" rating from the Annenberg Public Policy Center.
An informative half-hour series that teaches about wild animals, natural habitats, and the environment.

Twelve-year old Sabrina Spellman, who is half witch and half mortal, is being raised in a non-traditional family consisting of her Uncle Quigley and two young aunts. Series episodes explore social and developmental issues such as peer pressure/competition, loyalty and friendship, responsibility, honesty, facing fears, speaking up for one's beliefs, etc. Family issues such as divorce and remarriage and household rules are also addressed.

column7: Disney's Weekenders, Disney's Recess, Teacher's Pet
column16: This two-hour program block features three half-hour educational series in combination with a variety of short-form educational and entertainment elements which include "Great Minds. . . Think for Themselves" (American History segments), "ABC's Schoolhouse Rock" and fact-based shorts called "What's Up With That?" "Weekenders" revolves around four friends' quest for the ultimate weekend. This quartet spends each weekend discovering new levels of fun, all the while negotiating the obstacles of adolescence. Each episode follows a story from Friday afternoon to Sunday evening. The series is designated as children's educational and informational programming. "Disney's Recess" is a collection of animated stories about a group of fourth graders who attend suburban public school. Having been loyal friends for years, these children are an ethnically and gender-diverse group. They provide role models for viewers who may likewise be struggling with problems common to middle childhood such as conflicts with authority figures, school and family rules, desire to be popular, peer pressure, crisis's of confidence, lack of fairness. A recurrent theme is the issue of dealing with the class bully or "teacher's pet." Certain episodes raise thought-provoking questions which parents and children can talk about together, providing a rich source of value-oriented family discussion material. "Teacher's Pet" stresses the value of education and underscores the privilege of being able to attend school. Story lines illustrate the importance of honesty, cooperation, peer teamwork, problem solving, respect for rules and empathy. "Spot/Scott's" extraordinary vocabulary introduces children to new vocabulary and the skill of deducing meaning from context.

Narrated via the spoken journal entries of aspiring writer/cartoonist Doug Funnie, this series uses humor and fantasy in depicting the struggles of a twelve-year old boy to develop self-confidence and identity, resolve family, peer and school problems and maintain friendships strained by preadolescent physical and emotional change. Series episodes foster values such as honesty, loyalty, fairness and respect for individual differences. By means of its narrative episode structure, "Brand Spanking New! Doug" also serves to encourage creative writing and artistic expression.
A locally produced series for young children that features a resident cast of performers who deliver a pro-active social/moral message through songs and skits.

The program invites children into the great outdoors to explore the world around them. The outdoor magazine, exclusively geared to kids, explores such varied topics as the stars and planets, construction of a tee-pee, surf kayaking and orienteering.

column7: The New Adventures of Winnie the Pooh
column16: Based on the timeless characters from the renowned children's books by A.A. Milne, "Winnie The Pooh" centers on lovable Pooh bear and the humorous adventures he shares with Tigger, Piglet, Christopher Robin and their other friends. The series has won numerous awards, including the Emmy for Best Children's Series in 1991 and Humanitas Awards in 1989 and 1992.

The program teaches young adults about the attributes, habits, dangers and threats related to diverse wild animal species. By highlighting the ecological significance of each animal features, "Wild Moments" stresses the importance of conservation and provides pro-active information to motivate young viewers to honor and preserve wild animals. Professor Norman Feshback, at the UCLA Graduate School of Education and Informal Studies, acts as consultant for the program.

To celebrate the accomplishments of the national and local Jefferson Award recipients, the American Institute for Public Service produces and distributes a national television special. Created in 1989, this program is the first television event to highlight excellence in service to America. Over nine years, the Institute has built the special to air in over 140 markets, including 8 out of the top 10, reaching more than 10 million Americans. Never before has there been such a vehicle reminding all of us that one person can make a difference.

"High 5", a regular news feature throughout the school year, represents a year-long commitment to recognize the outstanding achievements of high school athletes. On Thanksgiving Day, the news department produces this live half-hour special highlighting high school athletes in championship games.
This national talent search program seeks to recognize students who excel in science and in the performing arts. Sponsored by the NAACP.

The program features classic holiday carols set against the majestic backdrop of Boston's Symphony Hall. The program provides a time for families to enjoy together the beauty of the holiday season and traditions. A children's chorus and young soloists energize the appreciation for orchestral and choral music.

column7: New England Storm of the Century
column16: A documentary featuring the major weather disasters that have shaken New Englad since 1900. WCVB's Principal Meteorologist, Dick Albert, hosts this special look at the destructive power of Mother Nature over the course of the 20th century.

column7: Winnie the Pooh and Christmas, Too
column16: Pooh and Piglet retrieve a letter to Santa, but while trying to add some forgotten Christmas wishes, their plans go amiss. Realizing the letter won't find its way to the North Pole in time, Pooh and Piglet decide to find Santa, with some decidedly comedic results. The program highlights the importance of friendship and helping others.

Each episode follows Jack Hanna as he spends time with animals from all continents. Jack interviews people knowledgeable about each animal and their habitat. Children will learn about ecology, respnosibility for the environment and sharing the planet with the animals.

Children will learn about ecology, respnosibility for the environment and sharing the planet with the animals.

Children will learn about ecology, respnosibility for the environment and sharing the planet with the animals.

Each episode follows Jack Hanna as he spends time with animals from all continents. Jack interviews people knowledgeable about each animal and their habitat. Children will learn about ecology, respnosibility for the environment and sharing the planet with the animals.

A significant purpose of Scholastic’s “The Magic School Bus” is to educate and inform children between the ages of 6 and 9. The educational and informational objectives of the series are to: motivate children’s interest in science; introduce science ideas; inspire positive attitudes toward science and education; and model age appropriate science problem solving behavior. Each of the fifty-two half-hour episodes explores a different science topic through an animated journey aboard the magically transformed school bus to destinations such as the center of the earth, inside the human body, to outer space, to remote ecological environments, inside of a molecule, and inside of a plant. The program is regularly scheduled and airs between the hours of 7:00 am and 10:00 pm. The program is 30 minutes in length, and is identified as an educational and informational show, targeted to 6 to 9 year olds, at the beginning of each broadcast and in listings provided to publishers of program guides.

NFL “Under The Helmet” showcases the pro-social on and off the field activities of the NFL’s leading players and coaches. Working with the National Association for Sports and Physical Education, the program (1) educates teens about dedication, hard work, teamwork, goal setting and community service, (2) provides examples of responsible social and personal behavior, (3) demonstrates how to deal constructively with the differences among people, and (4) teaches the benefits of physical activity and fitness. The program is regularly scheduled and airs between the hours of 7:00 am and 10:00 pm. The program is 30 minutes in length, and is identified as an educational and informational show, targeted to teens (13-16 year olds), at the beginning of each broadcast and in listings provided to publishers of program guides.

The objective of this series is to educate and inform children by bringing them the most entertaining and interesting stories about the world's most fascinating animals. Each episode consists of at least 4 stories designed to teach children about exotic and unique animals from the wild, as well as to educate them further about animals seen in everyday life.

The educational goal of the program is to provide an opportunity to discover new ideas and information about animals and their interrelationship with humans. The show is also intended to teach children the need to be respectful of each other and their environment.

The educational objective of this program is to introduce the teen audience to the pro-social, off-court activities of basketball players and other individuals, and to individuals who have overcome various obstacles in order to achieve their goals. The program segments are based on a curriculum inspired by the U.S. Department of Education's Goals 2000, with particular focus on messages encouraging the following values: school completion, community service, cooperation, tolerance of differences, healthful practices and athletics, peaceful conflict resolutions and global awareness. These educational and informational messages are conveyed primarily through real life examples, interviews and commentary by the program's hosts.

The educational objective of this program is to take the viewer from one level of knowledge to a more informed or higher level of knowledge within each episode. This is achieved through the storylines, where one or more of the three main characters will demonstrate active problem-solving and decision-making related to a specific topic. Topics include, for example, racial identity, understanding and accepting loss, facing failure, effective communication, conclict management, personal responsibility, service to thers, trust and betrayal, academic achievement, life balance, and tolerance.

The educational objective of this program is to demonstrate how the knowledge of one or more characters in the story moves from one level to a more informed or higher level of knowledge by the end of each episode. This change in knowledge conveys an educational message to the audience which may fall into one or more categories- intellectual-cognitive and/or socio-emotional. The message will always be integral to the plot and present throughout the script. This objective is achieved in this series by examining how a boy's team accepts a female player, and by exploring themes related to group processes, such as teamwork, reciprocity, cooperation and competition, tolerance and acceptance. As the team and their close friends go through each basketball season, they face new challenges and solve problems through individual effort and mutual support.

The educational objective of this program is to demonstrate how the knowledge of one or more characters in the story moves from one level to a more informed or higher level of knowledge by the end of each episode. This change in knowledge conveys an educational message to the audience which may fall into one or more categories- intellectual-cognitive and/or socio-emotional. The message will always be integral to the plot and present throughout the script. This objective is achieved in this series by exploring the pressures of living in a big city environment where situations are sometimes so difficult and challenging, kids have to learn sophisticated and responsible decision-making to be safe and stay focused. The series follows the encounters and problem-solving of two young men through an eventful school year at Manhattan High and shows teens how to work with their principal, family and friends to be successful.

The educational objective of this program is to demonstrate how the knowledge of one or more characters in the story moves from one level to a more informed or higher level of knowledge by the end of each episode. This change in knowledge conveys an educational message to the audience which may fall into one or more categories -- intellectual-cognitive and/or socio-emotional. The message will always be integral to the plot and present throughout the script. This objective is achieved through this series by exploring socio-emotional themes of identity, self-worth, social reciprocity, service to others and acceptance of differences. Through the characters in the show, our audience will see examples of different approaches to resolving problems caused by these issues.

The educational objective of this program is to demonstrate how the knowledge of one or more characters in the story moves from one level to a more informed or higher level of knowledge by the end of each episode. This change in knowledge conveys an educational message to the audience which may fall into one or more categories- intellectual-cognitive and/or socio-emotional. The message will always be integral to the plot and present throughout the script. This objective is achieved in this series by exploring the pressures of living in a big city environment where situations are sometimes so difficult and challenging, kids have to learn sophisticated and responsible decision-making to be safe and stay focused. The series follows the encounters and problem-solving of two young men through an eventful school year at Manhattan High and shows teens how to work with their principal, family and friends to be successful.

The High School Sports Show is a half hour program aimed at teens which focuses on the positive aspects of high school students, teams and coaches. There are feature stories such as Athlete of the Week and Scholastic Honor Roll that focus on those that have overcome adversity of one kind or another; highlighting a student's achievements in the classroom as well as on the field. The overall positive attitude and academic emphasis of the program helps in the emotional and social education of 13-16 year olds by focusing on stories where teens excel in a particular sport, overcome adversity to achieve goals, or talk about their future athletic and academic goals. To the teen viewers, the outstanding student athletes profiled on the show serve as real role models, sharing the secrets of their high school success. In addition, coming in and out of each commercial break "Stay in School," "Don't Do Drugs," and other public service bumps are used to help educate and inform the targeted 13-16 year old viewers.

The High School Sports Show is a half hour program aimed at teens which focuses on the positive aspects of high school students, teams and coaches. There are feature stories such as Athlete of the Week and Scholastic Honor Roll that focus on those that have overcome adversity of one kind or another; highlighting a student's achievements in the classroom as well as on the field. The overall positive attitude and academic emphasis of the program helps in the emotional and social education of 13-16 year olds by focusing on stories where teens excel in a particular sport, overcome adversity to achieve goals, or talk about their future athletic and academic goals. To the teen viewers, the outstanding student athletes profiled on the show serve as real role models, sharing the secrets of their high school success. In addition, coming in and out of each commercial break "Stay in School," "Don't Do Drugs," and other public service bumps are used to help educate and inform the targeted 13-16 year old viewers. *WHDH aired a special addition of this show on 12/30/00 with a repeat on 12/31/00. This special, The American Hgh School Sports Show, focused on high school students who nationally have stood out among their other teammates and made a significant contribution to high school sports.

This half-hour series features fascinating "awesome adventures" for children every week. Children can experience volcanic explorations, the rapids of the Salmon River and Safaris throughout the world. This program informs, entertains, and educates children about the history and cultures of the places visited.

A significant purpose of this half-hour magazine show is to educate and inform children, ages 2-11 about principles of science and nature. Beakman, an inquisitive scientist and the show's host answer children's questions about how the world works though revealing the relationship between principles of science and nature and explaining how they impact our daily lives. Beakman also performs entertaining and eye-opening experiments enhanced with state of the art visuals, which make learning fun and understandable for children.

A significant purpose of this half-hour program is to educate young viewers about the importance of preserving and protecting our natural resources, wildlife and the environment. Note: 12/9/00: Pre-emption was due technical difficulties. WHUB-TV lost it's signal to transmit. The program was madegood same day from 3-3:30pm E.T.

Detention is an animated series revolving around the boys and girls of the Benedict Arnold Middle School. By focusing on the relationships, adventures, and concerns of a group of middle school students, the series provides the young viewing audience with a non-threatening arena from which to observe and learn from the actions of others. Learning is engaging, natural and becomes part of the overall fun of the show.

Histeria is an animated series intended to keep history alive by supplying youngsters with a portion of the historical frame of reference missing in the schools, and challenge them to proceed with future learning. The learning objective and goals are fully integrated with the story lines, characters and the historical settings dealt with in "Histeria." In this way, new knowledge and learning skills become part of the overall fun of the series.

column7: Jim Fowler's Life in the Wild
column16: The key educational objective of this program is to create awareness and understanding of animals, and their interaction with their particular environment. Further, the role that humans play interacting with animals in the wild will be consistently explored.

Generation O! seeks to engage and delight young, grade-school children while promoting positive pro-social models of life-skills and character development as it portrays how an eight-year-old "normal kid/famous rock star" deals with the kinds of day-to-day problems that all children must confront.

column7: Jim Fowler's Life in the Wild
column16: The key educational objective of this program is to create awareness and understanding of animals, and their interaction with their particular environment. Further, the role that humans play interacting with animals in the wild will be consistently explored.

column7: One Person Can Make a Difference
column16: This WB56 News/FamilyFirst prime-time special on Team Harmony VII, “One Person Can Make A Difference” has the goal to motivate young people to make a positive difference in their lives. On Tuesday, December 5 with camera and mic in hand, WB56 captured live footage of thousands of local teens at the FleetCenter for Team Harmony VII. WB56’s “Ten O’Clock News” Anchors Karen Marinella and Jeff Barnd went behind-the-scenes, interviewing key-note speakers, performers, some amazing kids and motivating teachers who all “made a difference” at this year’s event. By combining entertainment, education and inspiration, the prime-time special will help spread Team Harmony’s anti-discrimination message throughout Massachusetts.

New Zoo Review is a non-violent and enlightening program focusing on ethical, moral, and social issues. It received a four star rating from NEA and it is recognized by the National School Board. Each of the 195 episodes develops a variety of ethical, moral, and social issues (i.e. being neat, being yourself, sports, optimism, etc.) that can influence the behavior of young children in a very positive way. We continue to air this show because it is difficult to find an alternative to influence, positively and harmlessly, young children (3-12) as does New Zoo Review.

This two-hour program block features three half-hour educational series in combination with various short-form educational elements. The latter include "Find Out Why" (physical science shorts produced in association with the National Science Foundation), "Great Minds ... Think for Themselves" (American history segments voiced by Robin Williams), "What's My Name?" (facts about interesting figures in world history), "What's the Diff" (game segments that teach visual discrimination and analytical skills), "Let's Go!" (geography and cultural information segments) and "Flyndiggery Do: Where'd it Go?" (short segments describing animal behavior). "Disney's Recess" is a collection of animated stories about six fourth-grade children who attend public school. These children are an ethnically and gender-diverse group. Their experiences at Third Street School deliver messages about problems common to middle childhood: conflicts with authority figures, school and family rules, issues of fairness, peer pressure and coping with disappointment. A number of episodes revolve around class bullies or teacher's pets. Series episodes provide opportunities for parent/child discussions about values. "Disney's The Weekenders" introduces four twelve-year-olds who have been friends since kindergarten. They attend middle school in southern California and spend time together on weekends. Their family circumstances are diverse: Tino is the only son of a single mother; Carver is the middle child in an affluent African-American family; Tish comes from an Easteren European immigrant family and Lor is the only girl among fourteen sports-minded brothers. Stories explore topics such as parent/child relations, sibling rivalry, acculturation, competition vs. compromise, responsibility, honesty, peer acceptance and loyalty. "Disney's Teacher's Pet" - Via a magical transformation, nine-year-old Leonard Helperman's dog, Spot, discovers that he is able to talk and walk upright. He seizes the opportunity to fulfill a lifelong ambition - to go to school. Dressed in some of Leonard's clothes, Spot becomes Scott Leadready reveling in the challenge of learning fourth-grade spelling, math and history. The fourth-grade teacher, Mrs. Helperman, is Leonard's mother. She is also a single parent. This series is built around the privilege of being able to attend school and the value of education. Stories teach honesty, cooperation, peer team work, problem-solving, respect for rules (particularly in the school setting) and empathy. Spot's/Scott's extraordinarily wide vocabulary introduces children to new vocabulary and its meaning in context.

This series introduces four twelve-year-olds that have been friends since kindergarten. They attend middle school in southern California and spend time together on weekends. Their family circumstances are diverse: Tino is the only son of a single mother; Carver is the middle child in an affluent African-American family; Tish comes from an Eastern European immigrant family and Lor is the only girl among fourteen sports-minded brothers. Stories explore topics such as parent/child relations, sibling rivalry, acculturation, competition vs. compromise, responsibility, honesty, peer acceptance and loyalty.

A number of episodes revolve around class bullies or teacher's pets. Series episodes provide opportunities for parent/child discussions about values.

A number of episodes revolve around class bullies or teacher's pets. Series episodes provide opportunities for parent/child discussions about values.

Pepper Ann is the daughter of a single working mother. She loves math and science and hopes to some day make a name for herself in biology or medicine. Pepper Ann and her Hazelnut Middle School friends demonstrate individuality, problem solving, perseverance, responsibility and creativity. While the primary educational focus of the series is building self-esteem, particularly that of girls, stories also break down gender and ethnic stereotypes and broaden the definition of "family".

This series uses humor and fantasy in depicting a twelve-year-old boy's struggles to develop self-confidence, define identity, resolve family and school problems and maintain friendships. Narrated via the journal entries of aspiring writer/cartoonist Doug Funnie, episodes promote values such as honesty, loyalty, fairness and respect for individual differences. These stories also encourage creative writing and artistic expression.

Twelve-year-old Sabrina Spellman, who is half witch and half mortal, is being raised in a non-traditional family consisting of her Uncle Quigley and two young aunts. Series episodes explore social and developmental issues such as peer pressure/competition, loyalty and friendship, responsibility, honesty, facing fears, speaking up for one's beliefs, etc.. Family issues such as divorce and remarriage and household rules are also addressed.

column7: Winnie the Pooh and Christmas, Too
column16: Based on the classic "Winnie the Pooh" books by A.A. Milne, "Winnie the Pooh and Christmas, Too" depicts Christopher Robin and his companions (Pooh, Piglet, Rabbit, Tigger, Eeyore, Owl and Gopher) dealing with holiday gift giving. Each one comes to realize that holiday happiness is derived from giving, not receiving, and that being with friends is the nicest gift of all.
LIL' IGUANA IA A TALKING IGUANA PUPPET WHO, TOGETHER WITH HIS HUMAN CO-HORTS, TEACHES KIDS ABOUT SAFETY, TAKING CARE OF THEMSELVES AND OTHERS. tHIS IS DONE THROUGH FUN SONGS AND SKITS.
THIS SHOW TEACHES KIDS HOW CARS, TRUCKS, TRAINS AND OTHER THINGS RUN, HOW THEY ARE BUILT, ETC. IT'S VERY EDUCATIONAL AND SHOWS KIDS HOW TO RESPECT MACHINES AND USE THEM WISELY.

JACK HANNA TAKES VIEWERS TO FOREIGN LANDS TO LEARN ABOUT THE ANIMALS THAT LIVE IN THE REGION. RESPECT FOR NATURE AND ANIMALS IS TAUGHT AS JACK EXPLAINS THAT ANIMALS ARE NOT TO BE FEARED, BUT RESPECTED.

THIS SHOW ILLUSTRATES, THROUGH LIVE FOOTAGE AND MUSIC, JUST HOW THINGS ARE MADE. IT SHOWS THE MANUFACTURING PROCESS, FROM BEGINNING TO END, OF SUCH THINGS AS CANDY, TOY TRAINS, LAWN MOWERS, ETC. IT SHOWS VIEWERS HOW DESIGN AND PLANNING ARE IMPORTANT TO GET THE DESIRED RESULTS.

A FAMILY HAS LOST ITS MOTHER. TO RECOVER, THE FATHER ENLISTS HIS TWO FRIENDS TO TEACH HIS THREE DAUGHTERS GOOD ETHICS, MORAL AND MANNERS. EVERYONE IN THE FAMILY LEARNS SOME THINGS ABOUT THEMSELVES, ALSO.

Each episode follows Jack Hanna as he spends time with animals from all continents. Jack interviews people knowledgeable about each animal and their habitat. Children will learn about ecology, respnosibility for the environment and sharing the planet with the animals.

Each episode follows Jack Hanna as he spends time with animals from all continents. Jack interviews people knowledgeable about each animal and their habitat. Children will learn about ecology, respnosibility for the environment and sharing the planet with the animals.

Jack Hanna's Animal Adventures is a live-action program designed to meet the educational and informational needs of children between the ages of 13 and 16. Children will learn about ecology, respnosibility for the environment and sharing the planet with the animals.

"Disney's Recess" follows the adventures and misadventures of six friends in their school playground as they struggle through the whirlwind of growing up. Issues covered include friendship, honesty, and the difference between right and wrong.

"Disney's Recess" follows the adventures and misadventures of six friends in their school playground as they struggle through the whirlwind of growing up. Issues covered include friendship, honesty, and the difference between right and wrong.
This local program explores the issue of violence, including gun violence, dating violence, and violence in the media, and how these issues affect local teens.
This episode tackles the issue of "surviving high school" in the New England area. We talk with teens throughout New England about fitting in, body image & eating disorders, and depression & suicide.

Disney's Doug follows the trials and tribulations of young man, Doug Funnie, and his friends, as they struggle through the ups and downs of growing up. Through Doug's relationships with family, friends, and teachers, issues like peer pressure, friendship, and honesty are explored

PROVIDES READING READINESS TRAINING, EARLY MATHEMATICS SKILLS, EDUCATION IN HEALTH, HYGEINE AND NUTRITION, AND PROVIDES ENCOURAGEMENT AND STIMULATION FOR ACADEMIC SUCCESS. PRODUCED BY CTW SPECIFICALLY FOR A SPANISH-LANGUAGE AUDIENCE.

"CARRUSEL" TEACHES LESSONS IN HISTORY AND GEOGRAPHY THAT THE VIEWER LEARNS ALONG WITH THE TELEVISION CLASSMATES. THE LESSONS ARE DEDICATED TO THE HISTORY OF THE AMERICAS, CONCENTRATING ON THE DISCOVERY AND SETTLING OF THE AMERICAS, THE HISTORY OF SLAVERY AND THE MEXICAN REVOLUTION. THE SHOW TEACHES THE IMPACT OF THE EXPLORATIONS AND DISCOVERY OF THE AMERICAS ON THE CONQUERORS AND THE INDIGENOUS PEOPLES. THE SERIES AIMS TO TEACH ALL CHILDREN OF THE AMERICAS BOUT THEIR COMMONALITY ROOTED IN THEIR SHARED ORIGINS.

Dora and her best friend, a monkey named Boots, invite the viewer to participate in an exciting adventure. Each step on the journey presents some kind of problem or puzzle and Dora is proudly bilingual, using that knowledge to communicate with her friends, overcome obstacles, and reach her goal. Dora enriches her world by providing preschoolers with lessons in language and culture while serving as a role model for children by developing self-confidence and a positive self-image by embracing herself for who she is, where she comes from, and what she will one day grow up to be.

Oye Arnold presents a fresh look at life in the big city from a child's point of view. The program focuses on Arnold, the principal character and his friends as they learn to deal with challenges, fears, temptations, and responsibility.

Oye Arnold presents a fresh look at life in the big city from a child's point of view. The program focuses on Arnold, the principal character and his friends as they learn to deal with challenges, fears, temptations, and responsibility.

Aventura en Panales takes children on a tour of the world that exists between your knees and the floor. It is a baby's-eye view of life that takes the main character, one-year-old Tommy Pickles, and his friends on adventures that explore the way everyday experiences can be fantastic. They discover magic, danger and comic adventure in our world. They venture into the unknown led by their curiosity and innocent love of mischief. The animation emphasizes perspective, often exaggerating sizes and shapes to reflect a child's point of view.

Lift-off is a storybook program. Each program presents a group of characters in a different adventure. Through these stories the protagonists, children, discover that they are able to face certain situations and resolve their daily problems. Each day a story teaches a different lesson regarding the community, friendship, relationships, and experiences they will encounter in the future. Children also learn the meaning of hope, perseverance, tolerance, and how dreams come true.

Pistas de Blue is an interactive pre-school program, which teaches children how to use the basic tools for critical thinking and reasoning, before going to school for the first time. Clues are given throughout the program by Steve the principal host and his dog Blue.
